abstract.p: Undesired noise and vibrations have a detrimental effect in many areas. Hence the control of vibrations has become a relevant technological challenge. Active vibration control of structures using smart materials is especially in vogue. This involves sensing the motion of the structure using sensors, generating a control signal using a controller and applying a control force on the structure using actuators. To design the control system of any vibrating structure, the mathematical model of the system is required. However, it is difficult to theoretically construct a model of complex structures. On the other hand, it is relatively simpler to model such systems in a Finite Element (FE) environment like ANSYS©. This paper deals with the extraction of the full and reduced mathematical models of a cantilever beam into MATLAB© from its FE model. The full model of the beam is reduced by discarding those modes which do not contribute to the overall response. It is found that the frequency and transient responses of the full and reduced models match closely. Hence the reduced model may be used to represent the system which in turn reduces the computational time. The controller is designed using proportional-integral-derivative theory with output feedback. SIMULINK© is then used to create a working block diagram of the control system and perform the control action. The transient responses of the controlled full and reduced models are then plotted which are found to be in close agreement. The procedure for the design of the controller described in this paper may be extended to control the vibrations of any real life system.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: In diverse areas like space and aircraft structures, satellites, cars, bridges etc. undesired vibrations are a major cause of problems. The effects of such vibrations are varied. Minor effects may include annoyance due to noise in automobiles, machines etc. Major effects are felt in areas like space structures where precise behavior of the structure is desired and any deviation from the required behavior may result in major expense. Under such conditions vibration control becomes very important.

Vibration control is an upcoming and challenging branch of mechanical engineering. It has wide ranging applications in diverse fields. A lot of research is being conducted in this area and new methods of control are being proposed and applied to the practical systems. Inparticular, active vibration control using smart materials is generating much interest around the world. Active vibration control is the process of using smart materials for controlling vibrations in real time. Smart materials are materials that respond with significant change in a property upon application of an external driving force. Such materials can act as sensors, which sense the disturbances in the structures, and actuators, which are capable of applying the controlling force. Examples of smart materials include piezoelectric materials, shape memory alloys, etc.

Some recent works are reported here. The active vibration control of simple cantilever beams is studied by many researchers. Piezoelectric patches as actuators are mounted on the beams. The system identification and pole placement control method is used by Manning et al. (2000). The beam with piezo-patches Finite Element (FE) model of the structure is constructed and the closed loop control is applied by Gaudenzi et al. (2000) and Bruant et al. (2000). Singh et al. (2003) also used the beam with piezo-patches FE model, but applied modal control strategies. Xu and Koko (2004) reported results on active vibration control of cantilever beam type of structures by using the commercial FE package ANSYS©. The influence of sensor/actuator location is studied for a cantilever type beam. Karagulle et al. (2004) extended the work of Xu and Koko (2004) and proposed the procedure for the simulation of active vibration control in ANSYS©, for cantilever and plate type of structures. Khot et al. (2008) used a reduced model of a cantilever beam to design the optimal controller using Linear Quadratic Regulator (LQR) algorithm with state feedback control law. Lim (2003) studied the vibration control of several modes of a clamped square plate by locating discrete sensor/actuator devices at points of maximum strain. Quek et al. (2003) presented an optimal placement strategy of piezoelectric sensor/actuator pairs for the vibration control of laminated composite plates. Xianmin et al. (2002) studied active vibration control in a four-bar linkage. Numerical simulations are reported in all the references given. Experimental results are also reported in some studies Manning et al. (2000), Gaudenzi et al. (2000) and Xu and Koko (2004).

In the present study piezoelectric patches are used as both sensor and actuator to control the vibration of a cantilever beam. The controller used here is a proportional-integral-derivative (PID) based output feedback controller. The state space mathematical model required for designing the controller in MATLAB© is extracted from the results of modal analysis of a cantilever beam done in ANSYS©. Both full and reduced models of the cantilever beam are used for the analysis and their responses are obtained in SIMULINK© environment.

sec.title: 2. Extraction of state space model from FE model
sec.p: To design the PID based output feedback controller for controlling vibrations of the cantilever beam under study, it is first required to obtain its mathematical model. In present study the required state space model of beam is extracted in MATLAB© from the result of its modal analysis done in ANSYS© (Hatch, 2001; Khot et al., 2008). Some important aspects of the model extraction procedure for a general dynamic system are explained in this section.

sec.title: 4. Extraction and reduction ofmathematical model of cantileverbeam
sec.p:
An aluminium beam of dimensions (504 mm × 25.4 mm × 0.8 mm) as shown in Figure 1 is used for the analysis. The elements used are ‘Solid 45’ for the beam and ‘Solid 5’ for the piezoelectric patches. The location of the piezoelectric sensor-actuator pair is determined based on the location of maximum strain. The Block Lanczos method is used for performing modal analysis of the beam in ANSYS© to find the eigenvalues and eigenvectors normalized with respect to mass. Ten modes are extracted. These results are then written to a file with extension. eig (Hatch, 2001). This file is then imported in MATLAB© and state space model is formed. Figure 1.
Representation of meshed cantilever beam.

By discarding the five modes which have least dcgain, the reduced model is also formed in MATLAB©. The frequency response of the system's full model is plotted in MATLAB© as shown in Figure 2. The contribution of each individual mode is also shown. Frequency responses of the full and reduced models are plotted in Figure 3 and transient responses of the two models are also plotted as shown in Figure 4 for comparing responses of two models. Figure 2.

It is seen that the reduced model response closely follows that of the full model. Hence a reduced mathematical model can be used for the purpose of designing the controller, which will save computational time. The transient responses of the MATLAB© and ANSYS© models are also compared as shown in the Figure 5. As the two responses closely match, the method used to extract the system model in MATLAB© is validated. Figure 5.

sec.title: 5. Pid based output feedback control
sec.p: The state space model of the cantilever beam extracted from ANSYS© is now used to design the PID based output feedback controller for actively controlling vibrations of the beam. In the PID controller the proportional, integral, and derivative terms are summed to calculate the output of the controller. The state space model is formulated in SIMULINK© environment. The PID loop accepts input in voltage form. For this reason the signal is passed through a displacement to a voltage converter block. For a piezoelectric patch the relationship between the displacement and corresponding voltage generated is given as (18) where, V is the voltage generated, X is displacement, T is thickness of the patch, L is length of the patch and d31 is the strain co-efficient for piezoelectric material. Since all the terms in the bracket in equation (18) are constant for a given crystal, the voltage generated is linearly related to the displacement. Thus a linear interpolation block may be used to calculate the values of the voltage corresponding to the displacement. This voltage is then fed to the PID based output feedback loop which consists of three main components; the PID controller block, the sensor block, and a voltage to displacement converter block. The PID controller takes the error signal as input. The error is calculated by the difference between the sensor signal and the input signal. When this error signal is substituted as e(t) in equation (17) the controlled displacement is given by u(t). To form the PID block, equation (19) may be represented as the sum of the outputs of three separate blocks as shown in Figure 6. To do so, the error signal may be split up into three branches, to provide input to each of the blocks. Figure 6.

The actuator block may be taken as a linear interpolation block which converts voltage generated to a corresponding displacement. It could be said to be the inverse of the displacement block explained earlier. The output of this block is fed to the ‘Scope’ for plotting the displacement versus time graph for the controlled system. A branch is taken out from this signal for sensor input. This block acts as a feedback for the control system. This signal is then fed to a summation point placed right before the PID based control loop as shown in Figure 7. It subtracts the sensor voltage signal from the input signal to generate the error signal. Figure 7.

An error may occur during the first running of the loop, as there is no output from the sensor. For this reason an initial guess of 0 volts may be taken as the sensor output as shown in the Figure 8. Thus when the loop is run for the first time, at the summation point, this zero is subtracted from the input signal. The systemblock diagram of the PID controller in the SIMULINK© environment is shown in the Figure 8. Figure 8.

The performance of a PID based controller loop depends upon the values of the three gains Kp, Ki and Kd. Thus, these values of the gains should be such that the overall effect would be optimum. For this reason the PID tuning block is used here. This block uses iterative method to calculate the optimum values for the gains. It tests each iteration on all possible instances of control action. The block then determines the most optimum instance and selects the corresponding values of the gains. The output of the PID based control loop is fed to a ‘Scope’ which plots the displacement versus time graph for the controlled system. Depending upon the values of the matrices A, B, C and D fed, it plots the graph for full and reduced models as shown in the Figure 9. Figure 9.

sec.title: 6. Conclusions
sec.p: In this paper, active vibration control of a cantilever beam has been demonstrated by using piezoelectric sensor/actuator and PID based output feedback controller. The mathematical model of the beam required for designing the controller is extracted in MATLAB© from the results of its modal analysis done in ANSYS©. The transient responses of the MATLAB© and ANSYS© models are found to be in close agreement which validated the process of model extraction. Model reduction is then performed and responses of full and reduced models are compared which also closely matched. A reduced model can serve to save the computational time required for the analysis. This procedure may be extended to any complex structure. The models of the beam thus obtained are then used to design a PID based output feedback controller in SIMULINK©. It is seen that the responses of full and reduced models are in close agreement. Hence by using the softwares such as ANSYS© and MATLAB© active vibration control of dynamic systems can be efficiently simulated which can give a close insight into the various aspects related to the active vibration control of real life systems.
